vfunc 1.0

    Function factorization with the vfunc package

    Robin K. S. Hankin

    vfunc.Rmd

    The vfunc package

    To cite the vfunc package in publications please use (R Core Team 2024). In mathematics, given two functions f,g:ℝ→ℝf,g\colon\mathbb{R}\longrightarrow\mathbb{R}, it is natural to define f+gf+g as the function that maps x∈ℝx\in\mathbb{R} to f(x)+g(x)f(x)+g(x). However, in base R (R Core Team 2024) this does not work:

    f <- function(x){x^2}
g <- function(x){1/(1-x)}
# f+g

    The vfunc package furnishes some ways to accomplish this.

    f <- as.vf(f)
g <- as.vf(g)
f+g
    ## An object of class "vf"
## function (...) 
## {
##     e1(...) + e2(...)
## }
## <bytecode: 0x5584c79c0090>
## <environment: 0x5584c79bfc68>

    Above, we coerce f and g to objects of S4 class vf [for “virtual function”]. Such objects have Arith methods defined and may be combined arithmetically; for example addition is dispatched to

    function(e1, e2){as.vf(function(...){e1(...) + e2(...)})}

    The vf class has a single .Data slot of type "function" which means that objects of this class inherit much of the behaviour of base class function; above, we see that e1 and e2 may be executed with their argument list directly. In practice this means that f+g behaves as intended:

    (f+g)(1:10)
    ##  [1]      Inf  3.00000  8.50000 15.66667 24.75000 35.80000 48.83333 63.85714
##  [9] 80.87500 99.88889

    The advantages of such idiom fall in to two main categories. Firstly, code can become considerably more compact; and secondly one can guard against a wide class of hard-to-find bugs. Now consider f() and g() to be trivariate functions, each taking three arguments, say,

    f <- function(x,y,z){x + x*y - x/z}
g <- function(x,y,z){x^2 - z}

    and x=1.2x=1.2, y=1.7y=1.7, z=4.3z=4.3. Given this, we wish to calculate

    (f(x,y,z)+g(x,y,z))(f(x,y,z)+4−2f(x,y,z)g(x,y,z)).(f(x,y,z) + g(x,y,z))(f(x,y,z) + 4 - 2f(x,y,z)g(x,y,z)).

    How would one code up such an expression in R? The standard way would be

     x <- 1.2
 y <- 1.7
 z <- 4.3       
(f(x,y,z) + g(x,y,z))*(f(x,y,z) + 4 - 2*f(x,y,z)*g(x,y,z))
    ## [1] 2.411975

    Note the repeated specification of argument list (x,y,z), repeated here five times. Now use the vfunc package:

    f <- as.vf(f)
g <- as.vf(g)
((f + g)*(f + 4 - 2*f*g))(x,y,z)
    ## [1] 2.411975

    See how the package allows one to “factorize’’ the argument list so it appears once, leading to more compact code. It is also arguably less error-prone, as the following example illustrates. Consider

    f(x+z,y+z,f(x,x,y)−g(x,x,y))+g(x+z,y+z,f(x,x,y)−g(x,x,y)) f(x+z,y+z,f(x,x,y)-g(x,x,y)) + g(x+z, y+z,f(x,x,y)-g(x,x,y))

    (such expressions arise in the study of dynamical systems). Note that functions ff and gg are to be evaluated with two distinct sets of arguments at different levels of nesting, namely (x,x,y)(x,x,y) at the inner level and (x+z,y+z,f(x,x,y)−g(x,x,y)(x+z,y+z,f(x,x,y)-g(x,x,y) at the outer. Standard R idiom would be

    f(x+z, y+z, f(x, x, y) - g(x, x, y)) + g(x+z, y+z, f(x, x, y) - g(x, x, y))
    ## [1] 64.04918

    The author can attest that finding bugs in such expressions can be difficult [it is easy to mistype (x,x,y) in one of its apparitions, and very hard to spot it]. However, vfunc idiom would be

    (f+g)(x+z, y+z, (f-g)(x, x, y))
    ## [1] 64.04918

    which is certainly shorter, arguably neater and at least the author finds such constructions considerably less error-prone.

    Note on primitive functions

    The R language includes a number of primitive functions as S4 Math generics, including the trig functions such as sin(), and a few others such as the cumulative sum cumsum(). These functions are quite deep-seated and cannot easily be modified to work with objects of class vf. The package uses capitalization. Using sin() as an example we have

    Sin
    ## An object of class "vf"
## function (x) 
## {
##     sin(x)
## }
## <bytecode: 0x5584c60ce710>
## <environment: namespace:vfunc>

    This construction allows one to define composite functions such as

    j <- as.vf(function(x,y){Cos(x) + Sin(x-y)})
k <- as.vf(function(x,y){Tan(x) + Log(x+y)})

    Then compare

    (j+k)(Sin, Cos + Exp)(Sin + Tan)(0.4)
    ## [1] 2.135028

    with

    j(sin(sin(0.4) + tan(0.4)), cos(sin(0.4) + tan(0.4)) + exp(sin(0.4) + tan(0.4))) + k(sin(sin(0.4) + tan(0.4)), cos(sin(0.4) + tan(0.4)) + exp(sin(0.4) + tan(0.4)))
    ## [1] 2.135028

    Conclusions

    References

    R Core Team. 2024. R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing. Vienna, Austria: R Foundation for Statistical Computing. https://www.R-project.org/.
